definitions.definition: a story created using the imagination, especially one that is full of action and adventure

examples.text: a coming-of-age/morality tale
The story is a classic tale of love and betrayal.
Dickens’ ‘A Tale of Two Cities’
His latest book is a delightful children’s tale about talking animals.
It's a moral tale about a baker and a shoemaker.
a dark tale of sexual obsession
a tale about a hungry snake
a tale set in 19th-century Moscow
an epic tale of courage and heroism
tales of adventure
the curious tale of the man who sold his hair
the rags-to-riches tale of an orphan who becomes a star

definitions.definition: an exciting spoken description of an event, which may not be completely true

examples.text: I love listening to his tales of life at sea.
I've heard tales of people seeing ghosts in that house.
She regaled us with tales of her wild youth.
The team's **tale of woe** continued on Saturday *(= they lost another match)*.
Her experiences provide a **cautionary tale** *(= a warning)* for us all.
She was tired of hearing the same dreary tale of drunkenness and violence.
the sorry tale of his marriage breakdown

definitions.definition: to survive a difficult or dangerous experience so that you can tell others what really happened
an old idea or belief that people now know is not correct
to give some information that is different from what you expect or have been told

examples.text: These drugs are widely believed to be effective medications. The data, however, tell a different story.

definitions.definition: to explain itself, without needing any further explanation or comment

examples.text: Her face told its own story.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody about something that another person has done wrong

wordOrigin: Old English talu ‘telling, something told’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch taal ‘speech’ and German Zahl ‘number’, also to tell.
